awd_titl_txt: Investigation of the mechanisms that drive intraseasonal Arctic surface air temperature variability during the winter
awd_abstract_narration:
The scientific objectives of this proposal are to advance understanding of the physical mechanisms behind day-to-month time scale variability in Arctic surface air temperature during the cold season. Over the past several decades, the Arctic has been warming twice as fast as the rest of the planet, and most of this warming has occurred during winter when the Arctic receives very little sunlight. Until recently, the primary research focus in Arctic science has been on warm season processes; however, recent studies show that during winter when there is virtually no sunlight over the Arctic, warm moist air associated with weather systems is transported from the midlatitudes into the Arctic.  These warm moist air intrusions, which can even warm high Arctic regions, have been occurring more frequently during recent years. 

This research will improve extended and seasonal prediction of Arctic sea ice. It will also support a graduate student. The team will collaborate with The Center for Science and The Schools (CSATS) at Penn State University to lead two single-day workshops on Arctic processes for middle school teachers from urban and rural Pennsylvania school districts serving populations highly underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and math fields. The workshop activity will enhance the teachers' awareness of the importance of studying the Arctic for the winter season. CSATS will evaluate the effectiveness of the workshop through pre/post tests, making necessary adjustments to the pedagogy sessions and activities for the second workshop.

Mechanisms that drive day-to-month variability of Arctic surface air temperature will be investigated. The evolution of dominant patterns of Arctic temperature field will be examined and quantified by performing surface energy budget analysis and moist static energy analysis for the atmosphere. The analysis will also include calculations of wave energy propagation. These data analyses will be complemented by computations with a numerical model of the atmosphere. The research will also include an examination of ocean currents and ocean temperatures, as well as sea ice data.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past several decades, the Arctic has been warming more rapidly than any other place on Earth. The warming has not just been confined to the surface and lower atmosphere where the changing temperatures can directly impact sea ice and the environment where people and wildlife inhabit, but also higher in the atmosphere into the stratosphere. These changes over the Arctic have received much attention not only from the climate science community but also from the public because of the unfolding and potential consequences on the lives of the people and wildlife, and on socioeconomic activities such as shipping and explorations of natural resources. For the most recent decade, it has been suggested that the warming Arctic has caused winter cold extreme weather to occur more frequently over part of North America and Siberia. In this NSF-funded project, the physical mechanisms that drive Arctic temperature variability were investigated. Counterintuitively, it is during the winter season that the warming has been most rapid.  Therefore, winter processes were the focus of this investigation.

The investigation led to the following research outcomes: 1. Over 50% of the multi-decadal warming trend over the Arctic can be explained by an uptick of the occurrence of certain weather patterns. The warming takes place as a result of southerly winds that bring warm and moist air into the Arctic from lower latitudes. This mechanism contrasts the long-held belief that the warming is caused by declining sea ice cover which is the legacy of the prior summer?s ocean warming. The PI?s group showed previously that the summer?s Arctic condition is influenced by the prior winter condition more so than the summer condition influences the following winter: 2. Those weather events, while warming the Arctic, also cool regions to its south, primarily in midlatitude land areas. Therefore, this outcome indicates that the warming of the Arctic and cooling of part of North America and Siberia are a consequence of the same global-scale weather system, rather than the former causing the latter: 3. This type of weather can be readily excited by latent heat release over the western tropical Pacific where tall cumulus clouds are populated over the warmest sea surface of the world.  In fact, the sea surface in the western tropical Pacific has been warming more rapidly than the eastern tropical Pacific. These outcomes indicate that somewhat paradoxically, a better understanding of the tropical Pacific climate system is needed for a more reliable projection of climate change at regional scales, including the Arctic.

The climate models are reliable in projecting global mean temperature, but there are systematic biases in projecting temperature and precipitation over certain regions. Because climate models are extensively used to project the future state of regional climate, it is important to be aware of those systematic model errors and the cause(s) of those errors. Climate models tend to underpredict the amount of warming over the Arctic. The climate models also have systematic biases in precipitation over some midlatitudes regions including western North America which has suffered from heat waves and wildfires. The cause of these model biases was also investigated. The investigation funded by this project shows that these model biases can be traced back to model biases in tropical precipitation. This outcome once again underscores the need to better understand and model the tropical climate system. The outcome provides a theoretical basis for considering observational trajectories (in addition to climate model projections) when it comes to making decisions responding to regional climate change.  

The results from this NSF award have been disseminated through 15 peer-review journal articles, 3 invited talks, 15 conference contributed presentations by graduate students, and 3 poster presentations. This NSF award also supported three graduate students? research activities at various stages, and helped inform rural middle and high school teachers about Arctic climate change through two Saturday workshops, one in State College, PA and the other near Pittsburgh, PA. Two of the graduate students received highly competitive Outstanding Oral Presentation Award by the American Meteorological Society. Two of the students graduated in 2021. They are off to a great start of their research career by being selected for the Postdoctoral Fellowship offered by Atmospheric and Oceanic Science Program at Princeton University.
